abstract:
The International Consumer Electronics Show cannot be ignored, reports Nick Wingfield, one of The New York Times reporters at the annual technology extravaganza held in Las Vegas. But he writes that the changing nature of the technology industry is reflected in the fact that the most important developments are no longer coming from the show.

As the industry and its trade show have grown, the need for buzz and branding has become more acute. The most innovative players — like Apple and Amazon — need to stand out from the crowd and so have chosen to introduce their products at smaller, more narrowly defined conferences and company-only events.

The show is still important to many retailers, though, who either place orders or just get a look at new merchandise. But Apple and Amazon have brought changes to tech retailing because they sell directly to consumers. That has made them less dependent on the dwindling number of independent electronics retailers like Best Buy, which reported flat sales during December.

The New York Times’s coverage of the show is marshaled over on our sister site for personal technology news, Gadgetwise. Among the big themes the staff of The Times will be following are the rise of ultrabooks, the thin, light laptops that compete with the Macbook Airs; fitness devices that are linked to mobile device apps; and more tech for cars.
